text: there's something powerful and
mysterious about beholding the image of
a human face in The Passion of Joan of
Arc the Danish director Carl Dreyer
gives this experience and almost
spiritual intensity the real Joan of Arc
was a 15th century French peasant girl
who battled the English invaders was
tried and executed for heresy and went
on to become a saint in the Catholic
Church and a symbol of French national
pride the film is based on the actual
transcripts of the trial and explores
some of its political implications at
the time
Joan played by the extraordinary French
actress Maria Falconeri is interrogated
about her actions her motives her
religious beliefs her relationship with
God by a panel of judges who themselves
are an extraordinary and idiosyncratic
ensemble including notably the bizarre
French avant-garde literary figure
Antonin Artaud
the whole first half of the movie is
basically a succession of close-ups
which create a feeling of intimacy and
confinement and the drama even the
narrative itself are contained within
these phases
you
once Jones fate is sealed the movie
opens up acquainting us with the larger
world around Joan and the effects that
her death will have on it but the movie
is less interested in politics or in
history than it is in tracing the
currents of emotion that flow from Joan
to the crowd from Joan to her
inquisitors from Joan to God and from
Joan to us The Passion of Joan of Arc
creates an uncanny unforgettable almost
unique sense of connection to its main
character we may not ultimately
understand Joan but we know her
